conclusion: Break down the motion of the missile into two phases: the vertical phase and the curved phase.
The missile accelerates uniformly upward with an acceleration of 100 m/s^2 until it reaches an altitude of 5000 m.
Determine the time to reach 5000 m using the equation of motion for vertical displacement: t = 10 s.
Determine the velocity at 5000 m using the equation of motion for velocity: v = 1000 m/s.

The missile follows a curved trajectory until it hits the enemy aircraft. The initial velocity in the vertical direction is 1000 m/s and the initial velocity in the horizontal direction is 0 m/s. The angle of the jet direction is θ such that cos θ = 1/11.
Determine the components of the thrust force: vertical component is F sin θ and horizontal component is F cos θ.
Determine the acceleration in the vertical and horizontal directions: a_y = g - F sin θ/m and a_x = F cos θ/m.
The remaining distance to the enemy aircraft is 15000 m.
The horizontal component of the velocity is v_x = a_x t and the vertical component of the velocity is v_y = v_{y0} + a_y t, where v_{y0} = 1000 m/s.
Set up the equations for the horizontal and vertical displacements: x = v_x t and y = v_y t + 1/2 a_y t^2.
Solve the equations for the time and the thrust force: horizontal and vertical displacements must satisfy the conditions of the problem.
The final answer for the magnitude of the horizontal and vertical accelerations is a_x = F cos θ/m, a_y = g - F sin θ/m.
The exact numerical values for a_x and a_y would require the value of the thrust force F, which is not provided in the problem.
The final answer in terms of the given parameters is a_x = F cos θ/m, a_y = g - F sin θ/m.
